awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Innovation and Technology Entrepreneurship Cultures between Ghana, South China, and Silicon Valley
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will investigate contemporary social and technological processes that bring together and motivate specific kinds of leaders shaping transnational networks of design and innovation in computing and communication technologies.  Ethnographic research of tech entrepreneurship cultures in Accra (Ghana), Shenzhen (China), and Silicon Valley (USA) will document the complex reality of global technology production.  Who is at the forefront of molding these emergent relations? What are the daily practices in the design and implementation of new technologies between these regions, and what are the social, cultural and economic processes that shape them?  In both the high-end spaces of technology production and in the street-side low-tech stalls, technology entrepreneurs combine a range of tech skills and business acumen across borders to design, acquire, modify and distribute information technologies. All of these developments speak to a larger and currently unfolding transformation of where and how technology design and innovation take place.  By focusing on innovation and entrepreneurship cultures, this project fosters a nuanced understanding of how models of technology production are changing in a world that is growing more connected globally. It also shows how both resource-rich and resource-constrained environments are innovating transnationally, and identifies what can be learned from them.  

Specifically, the research engages with two groups of innovators: 1) transnational tech entrepreneurs making software and hardware products; 2) hardware sellers and manufacturing entrepreneurs who assemble, distribute and repair electronic devices. The first group is often found in start-ups, incubators, and tech hubs whereas the second group works from factories, repair shops, and electronic markets. While each of these works in particular networks, they are increasingly coming together as hardware prototyping becomes more affordable and software development readily available. The researchers will engage with both groups across their sites of operation, observing and interviewing them as is standard in ethnographic study. The underlying goal is to identify how circulating concepts in tech entrepreneurship and innovation like start-up culture, design thinking, and Internet of Things shape both local strategies and transnational relations of technology production.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
This research project has identified two timely phenomena: first, the impact of China?s roll-out of global development projects such as the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and Asia Bank technology innovation in the Global South and b) a widespread adoption of entrepreneurial training and investment programs that funnel young talent into the creation of regional innovation hubs. Findings demonstrate how these interrelated phenomena materialize across three regions and interrogate their implications for various actors, including entrepreneurs, policy makers, end users, etc. 

Intellectual Merit: Findings from this project contribute to research areas such as the social and cultural study of technology innovation and entrepreneurship, tech labor and the future of work, ICTD, and the political economy of technology production by offering insights into how the development of regional innovation hubs is contingent on a mix of national policies, global investment processes, and shifts in traditional supply chains. The research team conducted in-depth and long-term on-the-ground research in innovation spaces, factories, investment programs, and IT corporations across three regions: Shenzhen, Silicon Valley, and Accra. These local engagements with several key regions of technology innovation allowed the team to unearth not only how culture and regional politics impact technology design and production, but also shed light on both the deep interconnections (albeit often contested) between these three regions. 

Broader impacts: This project was uniquely timed to examine unfolding and drastically shifting relations between the U.S., Africa, and China, shaped by economic and geopolitical processes are enacted through technology and entrepreneurship. Findings unearthed how broader shift materialize on the ground through the perspectives of tech entrepreneurs, policy, mid-level managers, investors, and regional politicians. The research has provided concrete insights for policy and investment with regards to how an increasingly antagonist political relationship between these regions at times enables certain technology production, while hindering others. It also supports public understanding of how technology innovation is shaped by geopolitical and transnational processes of cooperation and entrepreneurship.

Key outcomes: This research has contributed to the publication of 2 books, 28 peer-reviewed conference publications and journal articles, the establishment of a new research center at the University of Michigan, and has supported three PhD students in their dissertation research and career development, as well as both PIs in institutional building, student mentorship, and successful career advancement. 

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Silvia Lindtner
